title-group.article-title: The Misreading of Solzhenitsyn's "Cancer Ward": Narrative and Interpretive Strategies in the Context of Censorship

permissions.copyright-statement: Copyright 1989 The Journal of Narrative Technique

ref.mixed-citation: "Moscow Writers on Cancer Ward'"-the transcript of the prose-section meeting at the Moscow Writers Organization, a section of the Union of Soviet Writers, November 17, 1966
Chambers, in Story and Situation
Shlomith Rimmon-Kenan: "Indeed, speaking of the implied author as a construct based on the text seems to me far safer than imagining it as a personified 'consciousness' or 'second self' " (87)
Jeffrey Meyers's 1983 article in Twentieth Century Literature
Michel Aucouturier, in "Solzhenitsyn's Art," an article in L'Herne, expresses the sym- bolic view of the novel.

Georges Nivat, in "On Solzhenitsyn's Symbolism," which appears in the same edition of L'Herne, speaks of symbolism based on "an immense network of apparently subordinate signs" that link together "the abandoned creatures" of Solzhenitsyn's various works" (49)
Vadim's role as an idealistic, dedicated Communist scientist is exemplified in Cancer Ward on pages 121-22, 203, 248-57, 289-90, 313-15, 382-84, 409, 414.
Shulubin's bad-faith cooperative life course receives emphasis in Cancer Ward on pages 382-84, 412-13, 435-48.
Irving Howe, in "Lukacs and Solzhenitsyn,"
Robert A. Maguire, in Red Virgin Soil: Soviet Literature in the 1920's (188-259)
Jakobson and Halle 60
Metaphor 78
Paul Ricoeur notes, "The metaphor is the result of the tension between two terms in a metaphorical utterance" (Interpretation Theory 50)
"Im- agination" 7
Interpretation Theory 50
Interpretation Theory 55
Freud's The Intepretation of Dreams
Abrams 36
Cuddon 385
Lemon 73-74
Interpretation Theory 59
Critical Essays 184
